newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - Foster's shares dip after Molson upset.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - Foster's shares dip after Molson upset.

text.p: Shares of Foster's Brewing Group Ltd were down four cents in a firming market on Monday after a Canadian tribunal ruled against a licensing deal between its Canadian associate, Molson Breweries, and U.S. brewer Adolph Coors Co.
The stock was trading at A$2.36 at 12.10 p.m. (0210 GMT), five cents weaker than Friday's strong close, while the All Ordinaries index was up 16 points or 0.69 percent.
Foster's hit a morning low of A$2.34.
But share analysts declined to attribute all of the fall to last Friday's tribunal decision.
The tribunal found that Molson breached its agreement with Coors Brewing Co by allowing Coor's U.S. rival, Miller Brewing Co, to buy a 20 percent of Molson.
"It's sheer profit-taking," said Michael Heffernan, head of equity research at Shaw Stockbroking in Sydney. Foster's closed on Friday at its highest closing price in at least two years.
"My view is it (the tribunal ruling) should not have any impact as such on Foster's -- on Molson, yes, but Foster's probably not," he said.
Molson said in a statement issued here by Foster's that the negative impact on Molson's profit would be material.
But the impact will not be known until talks between Molson and Coors, aimed at negotiating a new agreement, are concluded, Molson chief executive John Barnett said in the statement.
Molson, a unit of Molson Cos Ltd, is owned 40 percent by Foster's.

A Canadian arbitration panel ruled last Friday that Molson relinquished all rights to brew and distribute Coors brands when Miller, a unit of Philip Morris Cos Inc, bought 20 percent of Molson Breweries in April 1993.
The panel returned the Canadian rights to Coors and requires Molson Breweries to pay Coors all of Molson's profits derived from the sale of Coors products since April 1993.
Foster's analyst Greg Cathro, of Adelaide-based broker Todd Partners, said uncertainty would weigh on Foster's share price until the ruling's impact on profit was known.
"It's obviously not a mortal blow or a severe wound, but it's something that will create uncertainty," Cathro said.
